name: Copycat Little Caesar\'s Pretzel Crust Pizza
description: If you’re hankering for pizza takeout, let us show you how to make the copycat Little Caesar\'s pretzel crust pizza with just a few simple ingredients!
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup salsa con queso dip, such as Tostitos

recipeInstructions.name: Activate the yeast
recipeInstructions.text: In a stand mixer, dissolve the yeast and sugar in the warm water (about 110° to 115°F). Let the mixture stand until it’s frothy and bubbling, about five minutes. Editor's Tip: When yeast activates, it will bubble up into a tan foam. If your yeast does not do that, it’s not activated properly. Do not use it, or your bread won’t rise! Discard the mixture, and make sure your yeast hasn’t expired.

recipeInstructions.name: Mix the dough
recipeInstructions.text: Add the all-purpose flour and 1 teaspoon table salt to the yeast mixture. Using a dough hook, knead everything together on low speed just until the dough comes together, one to two minutes. Increase the speed to medium, and knead for five more minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: Proof the dough
recipeInstructions.text: Place the dough in a bowl that’s greased with olive oil, turning the dough once in the bowl to grease the top of the dough. Cover the bowl with a clean tea towel, and let the dough rise in a warm place until it has doubled in size, about 45 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: Shape the dough
recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 425°F. Punch down the dough, and press it into a 12-inch circle onto an ungreased 14-inch pizza pan. Let it stand 10 minutes. Editor’s Tip: One of our favorite homemade pizza tips is not using a rolling pin to roll out the dough. The rolling pin will push out way too much air, resulting in a paper-thin crust.

recipeInstructions.name: Turn the pizza crust into a pretzel one!
recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, carefully whisk together the hot water and baking soda until the baking soda is completely dissolved. Immediately brush the mixture over the outer 1 inch of the pizza dough (where the crust will be). Let the dough stand for five minutes, then repeat the process once. Sprinkle the coarse salt over outer edge.

recipeInstructions.name: Build with your toppings
recipeInstructions.text: Spread the queso dip on top of the dough, staying inside the crust. Sprinkle with cheese, and arrange the pepperoni on top. Editor's Tip: Don’t use too much sauce or too many toppings. Too much can make your pizza soggy and wet. You should still be able to see some of the dough after spooning on the sauce. As for the cheese, only use at most 1 cup.

recipeInstructions.name: Bake
recipeInstructions.text: Bake the pizza until the crust is dark golden brown (the color of a soft pretzel!) and the cheese is melted, 16 to 18 minutes. Gently brush the crust with melted butter before serving, being careful to not knock off any salt.

review.reviewBody: My family absolutely loved it! They said it was actually better than the Little Caesars one. Thanks so much for the recipe I see us making this one for years to come. Wish I could post a picture of it.

I've tried a few copycat recipes for pretzel pizza and this was the winner! The only changes I made were to make my own cheese sauce for it and I sprinkled some shredded asiago/romano/parmesean on top after it was done cooking.

Hi! Regarding the "does it taste the same" portion of this article, I used to work at Little Caesars during the first run of the pretzel pizza all the way back in like 2015 haha, and I'm here to tell you that the way they get that pretzel crust is literally just stirring baking soda in water and brushing it on the crust, so you nailed it! One difference though is the cheese sauce is an "aged cheddar sauce" (their words, not mine) so maybe something like the fritos mild cheddar dip would be more accurate than a a queso dip. I'm going to try it this weekend and see if it works!
